p: These results are consistent with numerous reports affirming that the fatty acid profiles of insects reflect the composition of their food [ 9], thus reinforcing the fact that the nutritive value of insect meal could be amplified by acting on the alimentary substrate [ 29]. Moreover, although the fatty acid content of silkworm pupae is different from that of fish meal, which is especially rich in long chain n-3 polyunsatured fatty acids, the high content of C 18:3, a precursor of the n-3 series, makes these insects good candidates as oil sources in the formulation of feedstuff.
